section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Books: Rain, We Read, The Jacket; toys or cut-outs of a worm, a rabbit, and a jaguar; drawing supplies

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read The Earth Book. Now we will read three Alphabet Books and look for r, w, and j in the words we see.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Rr, Ww, Jj Alphabet Books Read through each of the books. For each book, stop and have children point to the target letter on the page, say the sound it makes, and name the picture for that letter.
Explain the Activity An author writes the words in a book and an illustrator creates the pictures. Sometimes, one person does both. Today, I will be the author and you will be the illustrator.

Set Up Show the rabbit and write Rabbits ride in rockets. Read the alliterative sentence and then have children say the sentence after you. What do you notice about most of the words in the sentence? Repeat to introduce the worm and the jaguar with the following sentences: Wonderful worms are wiggly and Jaguars juggle jellybeans.
Ask Invite each child to choose one sentence to illustrate. Then provide a copy of that sentence for them.

Extend While children are drawing, point to the letters Rr, Ww, or Jj on their pages and ask them to name the letter and the sound it makes. When children complete their drawings, put them together to make a book and read through the book together. Place the books in the library for children to share.
Writing Letters Rr, Ww, Jj Children may enjoy tracing over dotted letters, writing letters in the air, or making letters in a sand or salt tray.

Focus attention on each target picture in the book. Ask children to repeat the word with you, emphasizing the initial sound. Then help children identify the letter on the page. Invite children to trace the letter in the air and say its sound.
Invite children to find objects in the room that begin with the target sound. When they return to the small table, have them sort the objects and label them with sticky notes.

Be aware that some children whose home language is Spanish may pronounce the letters Jj with the /h/ sound. Take extra time, as needed, to help children produce the /j/ sound, both in isolation and with picture clues as shown in The Jacket. Note, too, that in Spanish, the letter r occurs only within a word, and the letter w is only found in words that come from languages other than Spanish.

To encourage a physical connection to the alliteration activity, invite children to act out the sentences. Read each sentence and have children repeat it and then act it out. Rabbits ride in rockets, Wonderful worms are wiggly, and Jaguars juggle jellybeans.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Provide nine or more classroom objects for replacing, such as paintbrushes, blocks, and so on.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read The Earth Book. In the book we saw people taking care of things in their environment. Each day we come to our classroom. It is our environment, and we have to take care of it.
We talked about how important it is to be responsible for the materials we have in our preK classroom. Let’s walk around the room and name some of the materials we have in our room.
We have many classroom materials. Remember that after each time you are finished using materials, it is your responsibility to put them back where they belong, leaving that area neat and organized.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Put out nine or more classroom materials from different areas of the room. Each object should come from the special place in the room where it is usually stored or found. Then, for example, hold up the paintbrush and ask, Where in the room does this belong? After children tell you, put the paintbrush where it belongs.

Ask Invite children to take turns choosing an object, naming it, and telling where it belongs. Then have that child return the object to its place. After the object is replaced, say, Good job! Thank you!
Talk About Classroom Jobs This is our classroom and together we all need to help to keep it neat. Ask children to suggest ways to keep each area’s materials neat and organized.

To limit the activity, show only two objects from two different classroom areas at a time. Give children a choice of places by saying, for example, Does the paintbrush belong near the sink or near the books? Then continue with two more objects from two other areas.
Provide these children with materials for making posters. Challenge them to choose one area and make a poster that shows the materials that belong in that area.

Invite multilingual learners to name the objects in their home language before they replace them where they belong. To encourage children to be proud of their home languages, ask the group to listen and then repeat the words in that language and in English.

For children who struggle with maintaining their focus, help them by stating each direction and having them repeat it to make sure they understand what is expected of them. When sending a child off to replace an object, tell him to hurry and come back so that the next child can have a turn.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Reusable materials (such as plastic containers, plastic bottles, paper towel rolls), paper plates, scissors, glue, and tape

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book The Earth Book. In the book we saw different ways to take care of the Earth. Besides recycling, we can sometimes reuse materials.
Today I have some materials that you can reuse. You can use your imagination and make something new and wonderful!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Present the materials. Now, put on your imagination caps and think.
Do the Activity Invite children to reuse the materials to create something new. While children work, discuss their ideas with them.
Share Invite children to share the things they created. Encourage them to name the items they used and describe what they did. Display their creations in a Reuse Museum.

Share Ideas and Materials Invite children to share their ideas about reusing materials. Set out a box where children can put materials for reuse, such as scraps of paper, clean plastic containers and lids, foil wrap, and yarn.

For younger children, you may wish to limit the number of choices of materials. Children may find it easier to create something when they have fewer choices. If they finish quickly, encourage them to use the materials to make something else.
Challenge children to name their creations. Help them label them and write a sentence about them after they share them with the group, but before you display them.

For this activity, pair multilingual learners with English-speaking children for the turn and talk part of the activity. As they work, ask children questions about the materials they are using to encourage their use of social studies words.

For children who are still struggling with using scissors, take time to sit with them and help them practice using the scissors. Point out that the scraps that they make can be added to the materials that all the children are using as they reuse and create.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather the Materials Activity Cards, masking tape, index cards

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the Big Chart of Big Ideas: You Can Help! Let’s think about different ways we can take care of our Earth.
Today we will be sorting cards with pictures of people doing different activities that show they are taking care of the Earth. We will sort the pictures into three sections on our table.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Use masking tape to divide the table into three sections. As children watch, label the sections Saving Water, Saving Electricity, and Recycling. After they are labeled, point to each section. Read the titles again to make sure children know the name of each section.

Ask Show the children one Activity Card. What do you notice is happening in this picture? Is someone helping to save water, save electricity, or does it show someone recycling? Where should we place the card?
Repeat Continue until all the Activity Cards are sorted on the table. Then review the cards in each set. Encourage the use of science words as children describe the pictures.
Draw Pictures Have the children draw a picture showing something we can do to take care of the Earth.

To simplify the activity, only focus the children on two sections at a time. Ask questions, such as Is this picture showing recycling or saving water? After two sections are sorted, repeat the activity using only two sections.

To help children become aware of the vast uses of electricity, invite them to work with partners to make pictures of things people use that need energy from electricity to make them go. As they draw, ask them how each item can be used in a way to save energy.

Model and encourage multilingual learners to use a physical response for responding. In addition to discussing what they see in the picture, have them imitate what the children in the picture are doing. They might also express what they are doing in their home language.
For children who may find it difficult to make a specific drawing, help them by providing cutouts or stickers of things that they can use and then add to.
